title: Statistical Literacy Among Doctors Now Lower Than Chance
summary:
Key ideas
- A study of 4,000 doctors showed that only 42% of Ob/Gyn residents could correctly answer a true-false question on p-values.
- The same study showed that only 26% of doctors could answer a multiple-choice question on mammogram results, even though the question almost gave the correct answer.
- Doctors who got the statistics questions wrong were more likely to say they had good training in statistical literacy.
- Women rated their statistical literacy worse than men did, but did not actually do worse on the questions.
- Only 12% of doctors got both questions correct.

Key learnings
- Doctors' statistical knowledge may not be as good as we assume.
- Doctors who get basic statistics questions wrong may not be aware of how little they know.
- Women may underestimate their statistical knowledge compared to men.
- Even getting one question right may not make someone more likely to do well on the other.

Key questions
- Does this data suggest that doctors need more statistical education?
- Is it fair to expect doctors to know more about statistics than the general population?
- How can we ensure that doctors have the statistical knowledge they need to make informed decisions?
